reviewText:
Product received for free

Provided by Giveaways Reborn
Death by Game show is inspired by the great movie Idiocracy but goes beyond. A blend of strategy and twitch-based genres, baptized as ‚ÄúTwitch-Strategy‚Äù by the developers, and as such it might not be that normal tower defense and strategy game that one would expect. Forget about defeating waves of enemies on a single map with fixed building spots and upgrades, instead, embrace your limited freedom and walk freely on the map, trying to survive by strategically spawning droids and placing structures within a limited time.

PresentationThe game has a cartoonish 2D style with a unique feel to it. The focus lies on a futuristic look while keeping it as a tribute to those old game shows, maybe a bit too detailed which make it look messy, with too much going on, like the billboards filling the background of the battlefield with witty anecdotes; sadly there is not enough time to read them all, but the effect is still there.

The audio is very simplistic and yet very fitting, but sadly there isn't much variation in it, therefore it looses some attractiveness and might get irritating in a longer game run, considering that the soundtrack is pretty much the same as it fits the the theme perfectly.

As it a more casual game there is not very much voice acting going on. The lines are brought in an attempt to sound stupid and funny, but in the end the humorous might not get appreciated by all players and a bunch of references might go by unnoticed with the younger players.

PlotThe story plays in the future where robots dominate the human race. The player plays the role of U.H. Wutt. A typical fat nerdy human who is too smart according the droids and is sentenced to death because of it. The 'truth' about it all, is slowly reveal with the messages on the boards, the cries heard in the battle and many other elements in the background. The story also packs some parodies, references and puns from cult classics, but most of them can easily be missed by younger players, while olders might find it overdone. At the end, the story seems to disappear along the gameplay rather fast.

GameplayThe first level sort of acts like a tutorial but still leaves an aftertaste of confusion. A lacking of how to" or a the function of replay the tutorial makes the game confusing at times and might force the player to replay certain levels before realizing what needs to be done.

As the game will progress

reviewText: Death by Game Show is a 2D strategy- type of a indie tower defense game. Game is based in 26th century where apparently everyone else is stupid and our hero is way too smart and is therefor sentenced to rehabilitation. Rehabilitation turns out to be a TV-show where audience awaits your death and the main idea of the game is to avoid dying.\n\nRight from the beginning I found the graphics really appealing for an indie game, lacking only the differences between two of a kind of robots or buildings. Every explosion and critical hit is presented in a comic book- way which adds a nice little touch with matched sound effects. The one and only background tune that is constantly playing, however, quickly becomes annoying and you start wishing for any Justin Bieber song instead. Extra points for the Big Arnie's Get to da choppa!" phrase
date: always could be more of these!\n\nThe death match happens on a circular planet- map between two electric fences where you will have to use strategic skills and planning in a strategic view in order to destroy enemy robots and buildings
recommended: as there is never enough time nor energy. You spawn the robots by pressing keys 1 - 0 on your keyboard and build the buildings as well as use the boosters with your mouse
hoursPlayed: which sometimes didn't respond correctly to my actions.\n\nGame is fun for the first 40 minutes where you finish the tutorial and do some of the easy levels of the game. I found it hard to follow the instructions since there were a lot of text content on the screen
voteText: but after 5 minutes of playing you get used to the excess signs between every inch of the screen.\nAfter 40 minutes of playing
helpfulPercent: game becomes grinding hell where you need to run previous levels multiple times to buy yourself a good amount of boosters and buildings to finally pass the next round. Level 14 alone took me 40 minutes to pass
votesHelpful: even with 0% difficulty slider - which I think is way too long for an indie game that has 50 levels
votesTotal:
with even harder achievements.

Judgment
After a few level optimizations should become greater than Fallout Shelter! Game is totally worth its price.
PLUSSES AND MINUSES:

- difficulty of levels
- background tune becomes annoying after a while
- becomes grinding in terms of replaying

+ many levels
+ achievements and trading cards on Steam
+ random comments such as "Get to da choppa!"
+ hours of fun

GRAPHICS7MUSIC (TUNE)5CONTROLS8SOUND EFFECTS6STORY7
OVERALL RATE:		7"

reviewText:
Basic InformationTitle: Death by Game Show
Genre: Action, Indie, Strategy
Developer: Oointah
Publisher: UltraShock Gaming
Release Date: 22 Jan, 2016
General ImpressionDeath by Game Show is a pretty good combination of the action, indie and strategy genres. The graphics are well-designed for a two-dimensional game, pretty much basically cartoonish, but they are well detailed, fitting the game perfectly. The textures are pretty good as well, they are pretty detailed. The atmosphere takes place on Terra and in the Solar System, and basically on Terra you are on a stage where there is a show-designer, cameramen and random units around. In the Solar System, you will be sent on different planets with a rocket, and then released on the planet where you need to accomplish various objectives, differing from mission to mission. The audio is pretty nice, all of the sounds are well-optimized, as well as the soundtrack being great and funny. The gameplay is about a human who needs to fight the enemy droids with his friendly droids, which are being spawned by his buddy, which looks like a smiley locker. As the game will progress, the gameplay will only be getting harder and harder, and your buddy also has an energy bar, which needs to recharge if you spawned too many droids in a short time. You also must place buildings around the map, which will help with defeating the enemy droids, but some will help by generating other friendly droids. The story happens in the 26th century, and the show-designer keeps the story alive, until the end of the game. The controls are alright, there isn‚Äôt anything wrong with them. The engines are alright as well, I haven‚Äôt met any bugs, crashes, screen freezes or frame drops. This game works even with low-performant computers, as the store page says, making it accessible to any gamer. The mechanics are pretty nice, the enemies and buildings drop nicely when getting destroyed, and everything moves pretty good.
Positive Points Pretty nice 2D graphics and nice textures
Pretty good SFX and soundtrack
Fun and challenging gameplay
Many types of units and buildings
Many levels to combat (around 50)
The ability to construct buildings
The ability to spawn your own units
Integrated in-game level editor
Steam trading cards and achievements
Neutral Points The difficulty gets a bit too hard too early
The area of fighting could be a little longer probably
A multiplayer option would  be a great feature
Negative Points It gets a little confusing from time to time
Too much background text displayed around the maps
It could get repetitive for certain gamers sometimes
General Ratings
Feature	Rating	Graphics	78/100	Atmosphere	72/100	Audio	80/100	Music	82/100	Gameplay	76/100	Story	78/100	Content Quality	75/100	Content Quantity	72/100	User Interface	70/100	Controls	85/100	Engines	85/100	Mechanics	80/100	Price Tag	88/100	Personal Rating	79/100

reviewText:
Death by Game Show is a parody of reality shows, but with robots and over intelligent guy who happens to be the main character. He's to intelligent that he has to go for rehabilitation. Which will on us to stop that?

The beginning wasn't complicated, level 1 was a sort of tutorial. From my viewpoint, level 5 is where the challenge begins.  Something I didn't find amusing was the quantity of information the developers provided on the screen and there wasn't any pause button to read everything another time, so you'd have to be quick in understanding this game properly. It's easier to understand to unlock the various powers and achievements, but difficult to get all the money!

Graphics are really good. Sadly, there are a lot to read, like rules, and that's a big issue when you're playing. Rich colors and textures. I loved the 2D touch implemented.

Music was decent. I always appreciated good music but it's never always the main thing in a game. Ambience sounds were great, just as we expect in a TV reality show.

I recommend it! Lovely game, you can pass hours try to improve a level and get the achievements.

I really recommend this game, funny and with enough levels to get frustrated at.

reviewText:
Death by Game Show Review
Background Info:

I bought the game on release day, and waited to post this review so I could spend a decent amount of time with it. This is my personal review, not for any company and with no benefits towards myself.

Main Game Features:

Strategy/Tower Defense
Game show setting
Place buildings and send droids to win challenges
Asset Creation, Level Editor, and Text Editor.
Quick Comparison:

This is a very unique game. I honestly haven't found any other game like it (there may be one, but I have not come across it). However, if I had to compare it to something to help someone get a gist of if they'd like it. It would be a mix of Swords & Soldiers and Castlestorm.

First Impressions:

The first few levels are tutorials. Short and sweet to tell you the controls and get familiar with objectives. However, not the best I've experienced. It does well in explaining the core concepts of the game, but falls short when giving you extra (debatably benificial) information; such as shortcut keys, which can still be found within the game's controls" menu in settings. As well as
date:
giving you time to familiarize yourself with the different buildings.

Overall Gameplay:

You go through levels
hoursPlayed: placing buildings and sending out droids. It sounds like an easy concept
voteText: but this game very difficult. There is little to no hand holding
helpfulPercent: and that can be considered good or bad
votesHelpful: depending on the type of player you are.\n\nAs you play through a level
votesFunny: coins will fall on the ground and start sinking below the surface. You are equiped with a launch hook (grappling hook) which is used to pick up coins from a distance.\n\nThe main goal of every level is to board the rocket and fly back to safety. However
commentsCount: there are various objectives to complete before the rocket arrives. For example
column16: some levels may have you survive a certain amount of time before the rocket lands and you can enter
column17: others may have you collect a certain amount of coin.\n\nWhen you send out droids
column18: your G.I.M.P.'s energy meter goes down
column19: but does recharge over time. If the charge depletes
column20: G.I.M.P. falls to the ground and your movement is slowed. However
column21: you can still send out droids.\n\nThroughout levels you build up a spinner
column22: which hold either power-ups or extra cash.\n\nUpon completing a level
column23:
you get rewards (power-ups or buildings) to use in other levels.
Pros and Cons:

Pros:
Unique game
Extremely fun to play
Witty and commical writing
Challenging gameplay
Almost everything is customizable
Cons:
Challenging gameplay
Could use some gameplay tweaks
For The Developers:

I know you guys are planning to put out a patch at the end of this week
column24: but I'm still going to go over the game in it's current state.\n\n1. Entering a level
column25: the difficulty slider mostly just changes the rate that the enemies come out at
column26: and how much coin is dropped. So if I turn it down to make the game "easier" I feel like I'm also hindering myself because I'm not getting the coin I need to in order to get that objective. My opinion on this is to have the slider also lower the coin needed to pass the objective.\n\n1a. For example
column27: I was on a level that required $8
column29: 000 in order for the rocket to come. If I moved the slider down
column30: I felt it was harder for me to hit that coin mark
column31: because less coin was being dropped.\n\n2. I know the hotkeys are there for the droids
column32: but some people may prefer being able to see the coresponding number.\n\n2a. For example
column33:
Hammie would show a small number one in the bottom left corner.

Final Words:

Long story short
column34: buy this game. If you're a fan of any strategy and/or tower defense game
column35: you will not regret this purchase. I've mentioned before that the game gets challenging
column36: but on the same note - I'm not a very good player. Having said that
column37: I still really enjoy the game."

reviewText: Death by Game Show\n\nThis game is awesome! I did not really know what to expect but it really won me over. The game is basically a funny game show where you are a human who is deemed 'too smart' by the robot overlords. You then have to go through a series of challenges all the while building up your money and buying new items to beat the next stages. The humor is more mature in nature so be advised. Not too crass but not for children. The graphics are well done a crisp cartoony look. The sound is great and the little robots that you defeat and the ones you use of your own to defeat them with are funny and charming. After playing this for about 10 minutes I was hooked. The difficulty ramps up around stage 8 or 9 but even in the lower levels the game is just fun to play. I would rate this title an 8 out of 10. Well worth the money and has plenty of replay value.

reviewText:
A challenging little twist on Tower Defence games

In this game you're a human in a world run by robots. You've been deemed too smart by half and they will want to off on a tv show for the entertainment of all. Unlike most tower defence games, this game has a plot.

The game has a very unique look and a fitting sountrack. The gameplay is challenging and there's hours of fun to be had getting through the challenges and unlocking everything in this game.

Pros:
- Great look
- Excellent Soundrack
- Entertaining and challenging gameplay
- Reasonable price tag

Cons:
- Takes a few missions to understand the game

7.7/10

Definately recommended

reviewText:
Death By Gameshow
Love the name of the game, Right off the bat it has a Nicely Drawn intro with good music, lots of small humorous moments in the intro, The art style seems original I like it. The coloring of the intro to the first level reminds me of Magic School bus. Well onto the First Level, Not one for signs telling me what to do I went left and died lol
I like the stretcher carry away scene as you perish as well.
The concept is intresting. The Narators Voice is deep and cool when you die and beat the levels. I didn't see much gameshow connection in the first few levels of playing tho, besides the wheel that comes up to spin. The game is sort of like a tower defence game in the sense that you must survive waves of enemies to be able to beat the level.

reviewText:
This is really not your typical tower defense game!

You are intelligent man who has this giant cabinet chained to his body.

With that cabinet you could build several types of robots that will try to kill enemy robots for you.

Also you have buildings to start in some challenges. These could make automatically spawn some more robots or kill flying enemies etc..

Your mission here is to destroy enemy base by running around in this giant planet and after you have destroyed it you must escape through incoming spaceship within timelimit

You also have this nifty little claw hand what you use for grabbing things like coins, powerups etc.

There is also this red button that you have to build up by destroying enemies. When you press this button you get giant spinning wheel that will drop you powerups or money,

Conclusion to all of these: This is very positive and new kind of tower defense game that I would reccomend those who like to play these kind of games!

reviewText:
Before the game went on sale I spotted it in the listings and was attracted to the art style. It stood out and seemed like it had good deal of quality for me to follow up on and check out when it was released. So scooped it up on release day.

It hasn't dissappointed. So far I really like the game even though level 9 has me completely baffled after many retries and resets. With that said the game has a charm and enjoyment to it's style and presentation that with even being stuck on a level I'm still enjoying trying to figure out how to beat it. If the rest of the game is like this I'll enjoy it but I can probably see it not being for people who are prone  to punching monitors or smashing keyboards in fits of rage because a game isn't easy insta-win enough.

If there was one thing I wish it had that's missing is a hotkey system for picking the various units rather than having to  mouse click them. I find myself to be wanting to just use the mouse for grabbing dropped coins to get my wheel spins or level requirements. Having to do that and also clicking the right unit to build in the small list on the bottom is a bit of a juggling act when things get a bit frantic.

All-in-all a very well made game that's fun to play and look at. The hard work and thought put in by these devs definately shows. Better still is it's complete and not another early access.

reviewText:
To read my full review, click here; http://mousenjoypad.com/reviews/pc/death-by-game-show-review/

When I first heard about Death By Game Show, it was touted as a game inspired by the great film Idiocracy.  I would call it a guilty pleasure film, but it deserves more than that.  Then I read up on the game, discovering that the developers were also declaring this game was blending the strategy and twitch-based genres in what they coined as ‚ÄòTwitch-Strategy.‚Äô  Intrigued, I requested a copy and gave it a whirl.  I‚Äôm not a huge fan of strategy games, but like speed chess, the merger of speed with critical decision making was something that greatly interested me.

The game starts in the 26th century, where your character U.H. Watt stands trial for being too smart for a human.  You‚Äôre sentenced to rehabilitation, otherwise known as Death By Game Show.  This is the full extent of the story.  Obviously, when they said ‚Äòinspired by‚Äô the designers thought it meant referencing lines from the cult classic.  All of the writing is borrowed dialogue from a full gamut of films, including The Dark Knight, Office Space and even Predator‚Äôs ‚Äòget to the choppa‚Äô line.  If you still enjoy hammed up ‚ÄòAwnald‚Äô impersonations, then you‚Äôre going to love this game‚Äôs wacky sense of humor- sadly I found it kind of grating and childish.  The story is basically non-existent, so I‚Äôm going to move past it and looks towards the gameplay.

You‚Äôre transported to a planet at the beginning of every round, where you run around the planet‚Äôs surface with goals to accomplish before you can take back off on a rescue ship.  Despite it being a side-scrolling experience, the developers have utilized flying enemies to use the space above, buildings behind the front row that can only be taken out with particular robots, and coins that sink underground that you can pluck out with a claw right out of Bionic Commando.  You can also adjust the difficulty before a stage, with the lower the risk, the less coins your enemies will drop.

You‚Äôre strapped to The G.I.M.P. (Gameshow Intimidation Machine of Pwnage), an automatic and personified locker, which has a limited amount of energy as it shoots out your selected fighters.  If you push him past his limits (indicated at the lower left by a power meter), he‚Äôll fall over exhausted until his meter fills back up.  You can still send out robots while he‚Äôs down, but it‚Äôll be at a slower pace, and you‚Äôll have to drag it if you decide to move.  As you take out enemies and blow up buildings, you‚Äôll collect coins and upgraddes (the extra D is for a double dose of pimpin‚Äô).  Once you‚Äôve taken out the buildings or raise enough money, you return to the studio audience, and your money continues to rack up (as long as you don‚Äôt die).

I have to say- when I first started with the tutorial levels, I understood the innovative spark behind the design.  Being on a two-dimensional plane, you‚Äôre robots have a nice blend of offensive and defensive purposes, while you focus on grabbing coins that fall beneath the skirmishes.  You have a mobile wall that pushes back enemies and standard troopers you can send out to swarm the opposition.  There‚Äôs a fast-paced missile that blows up upon collision with an enemy building or robot, and flying robots that take out background infrastructures.  Your opponents come out of lockers as well, and you can see a timer counting down until their release.  It‚Äôs quite innovative.

Sadly, these ideas aren‚Äôt as developed as they need to be, and the strategy and choices evaporate as you get further along in the game.  This is clearly the opposite of how it‚Äôs supposed to be.  I should be getting more confident, and discovering new ways to utilize my abilities.  My paths should be growing instead of narrowing down to one.  Because everything starts moving at a breakneck speed with very limited resources, you‚Äôll discover a level‚Äôs needed order of attack, and what you‚Äôll need to defend against the pushback.  You don‚Äôt spend time strategizing; you‚Äôll just die, figure out what went wrong, adjust and try again.  Eventually, you‚Äôll ignore the coins that fall into the ground (they‚Äôre not worth the risk), and you‚Äôll be focused on remembering the patterns.  It‚Äôs more like learning an overly complicated dance fad, knowing that when you do finally nail it, it‚Äôll be meaningless, and you‚Äôll have to move onto the next one.

The game does try to change things up; perhaps a stage will be based on points, or destroying every building on the planet.  However, considering most of the time you‚Äôll need to kill everything to get the points you need, the goal of every stage is the same- leave nothing standing.  The game has particular power-ups you can only get through spinning the wheel, but they‚Äôre so far and in-between, you‚Äôll never have a nice reserve.  What would‚Äôve been nice is if I could‚Äôve used my money to buy additional units, but sadly the game doesn‚Äôt offer that- making money useless outside of high scores.

Visually, the game is very imaginative with character designs, but the frame is cluttered without any mercy.  The GUI just has too much going on for me to pay proper attention to any one area.  When you release robots, they speak with a giant text box saying some 90‚Äôs Back To The Future reference that fills the screen.  Huge black and white billboards have even more witty anecdotes, as planets rotate around the background as you move.  All this sensory overload doesn‚Äôt matter too much either, as most of the time your eyes will be planted on The G.I.M.P.‚Äôs power meter as you release enemies as quickly as you can.  The only time your eyes will be needed is when you look up to defend against hovering opponents or missiles.  Then, occasionally you‚Äôll get to spin a giant wheel that gives you a random perk- that ends up filling the screen while enemies continue to push towards you.

Mike Judge should be blushing because this new take on the strategy genre has been infused with his magical extract of vulgarity and satire. Regarding style, the game has a distinct feel. The speedy gameplay has an innovative approach. Sadly, the execution is entirely off, and everything from the mechanics to the audio comes across as muddled and half-baked. There‚Äôs simply too many missing opportunities to be recommended. Soon, ‚Äútwitch strategy‚Äù becomes as impressive as combining empathy and action into a ‚Äúwalking shooter.‚Äù I would only recommend this game to hardcore fans, who are willing to wade through poorly implemented ideas to experience this fast-paced strategy game.

I recommend this game to only hardcore fans, or those interested in the idea of breakneck strategy.

reviewText: If you want a game that mixes tower defense with robot mayhem, Death by Game Show is worth checking out.  The mechanics aren't hard to learn, but will take a lot of practice.  The challenges in the game will have you either surviving the onslaught or completing an objective (collecting money or destroying buildings) before timer goes out.  The game also has an Editor mode, which you can make your own challenge and present it to other players via Steam Workshop, which is a very nice feature to have.  However, I find the difficulty spike to be pretty rediculous and the grinding aspect of the game is really tedious.  However, I manage to have fun with Death by Game Show, and I'm always finding new ways to get through the challenges.\n\nRating: B

reviewText: This game is immensely fun, you can pick it up and play just a couple of levels but you will probably find yourself playing for hours. The replayability of the game comes in the form of trying the same levels over and over to finish them or get a high score, while this may sound dull the game manages to be quirky enough with the right mixture of different game-play elements that it never gets stale. The devs were not lying when they said the game is hard, sometimes it will take several attempts just to finish a level as you try and build up the required buildings and power ups via the 'spins' mechanic to complete a level, but when you do it feels very satisfying. I would recommend anyone who likes micromanagement, arcade or tower defence games to try this out. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
This key was obtained from evolve.pr for review purposes

Summary:
When it comes down to it, Death By Game Show will be for strategy players that has a high tolerance for frustration, and want something a bit different in the genre. The core strategy and the different combinations of buildings/robots leads to a lot of dynamic challenge that players will enjoy, it's just a bit rough to get accustomed to it while you fail over and over again. The dynamic difficulty setting and the real risk that comes with pushing forward with reckless abandon or not thinking about your next move will keep your mind thinking. So the core gameplay works well...it's just got a set of functionality around it that could use some improvement to make it easier to play. It's nice to see though that steam workshop support will be there, and I feel that it will make a huge difference for the life the game. The humor of the game is hit and miss, and that's really what I feel about the game in the end. It's going to be very hit and miss with the different audiences out there, and while it hit with me, be weary if you like more general strategy experiences, because this game will probably frustrate you.

Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5kOR7CyJ1Fo

Lists:
+:
Good strategy gameplay that forces change up in tactics, and does it with good enemy combinations in combination with the environments in question.
Those looking for a challenge will get it here. The dynamic difficulty selection gives a good risk/reward, especially with the fact that losing takes away all your money.
Each unit seems to have a specific purpose and strength, and blowing all you energy/robots on one type: you're going to have a bad time. Aggressive/defensive strategies can both work well depending on the objective.
Good reasons to go replay levels. The challenge is still there, and you get those extra items that can go a long way.
Like the coin system actually played in the spinner system. Getting money, which is your ultimate goal, had multiple purposes.
There's some good humor, in particular with the robot announcer in between rounds. Not the greatest, but still good.
-:
There's a steep learning curve. You'll fail a bunch at first....and you'll really be frustrated by the end of it.
The exploding enemies hitbox range feels rather deceptive, and several times that I thought I was out of the way of the blast radius, only to take damage. Led to some frustrating deaths.
UI should have hotkey indicators so that it's easy to associate the key number with the robot, without having to do math in the head internally.
While there's some humor that works, there's some parts that falls flat. Some repeated lines in particular really got on my nerves.
The pace of the game with pausing can really be up and down. Once you get more used to the game and it's mechanics, it gets better, but yeah, it's
Those with a low frustration tolerance: you're probably going to want to look elsewhere. With the losing of money and sometimes one hit going a long way to your death, it can cause some major anger.
The game has controller support......but the game is not designed for the controller at all. Awkward on a lot of levels to use, in particular with switching from the sets of buildings/robots/powerups.

reviewText:
IntroductionDeath by Game Show takes a new twist to what tower defence games are al about. Instead of being stuck onto a single map and having to defeat enemies wave after wave, Death by Game Show removes that element and replaces it with being able to walk around the battle feild spawning droids to help you survive.

GameplayThis game takes a new way of playing tower defence games, and makes this game a very unique one at that. The way that you play the game is you are on this planet, there will be enemy droids spawning that will try to kill you. You have your buddy, which I can't really indentify what it is, that spawns friendly droids that will kill the other droids. The first few levels are fairly simple, you spawn in a bunch of droids to survive until the ship gets back so you can exit the level. But after the first few easy tutorial levels have finished then the game starts to get a lot more strategic. You cannot simply spawn in a bunch of friendly droids to kill all the others, as there is a energy bar that limits you to how many you can spawn at once. This game is fairly fun and easy to pick up and play. With a nice variety of different droids and buildings that you can place down to hekp hold off the opposing droids, there really is a lot of content in this game to play around with for the strategic side of the game. The game does seem to take a steep difficulty curve when you hit a specific level, dying over and over until you can either win or just exit the game completely. The soundtrack on the otherhand is truly brilliant and well suited to this type of game. I feel like there needs to be a bit more content in the game generally, as the game does seem to get repetitve after a little while of paying the game.

The graphics of this game are alright enough to stand upon looking at. But after a while of playing the game, it does get a little bit boring to look out. I think that most of the levels don't have much variaion in the background, and just seem to be copied from the previous level and added some buildings that spawn new enemies around the map. Although some of the buildings do look nice, there still just seems to be a lack of variation in what is in the backgrounds of each level.

Pros+ Unique styled Tower defence game
+ Some nice graphics
+ A great soundtrack
+ Trading Cards & Achievements

Cons- Not much variation to background
- Gets repetitve after a while.

Result / Final thoughtsThis a very unique and interesting tower defence game that has some really nice graphics, but doesn't seem to have much variation when it comes to the background graphics. The soundtrack is brilliant, and the gameplay itself is fairly fun and simple to pick up after the first few levels. But, unfortunatly the game does seem to get repetitve after a while of playing the game.

Rating: 7.5/10

reviewText:
Death By Game Show ReviewBy Wilco

IntroAs of writing this review i have played 1.5 hours (90 minutes). I Will be writing about the gameplay and the graphics, i will also write about all the good and bad things i came across while playing the game.

GameplayIn this game you are a smart human, the world has been taken over by robots called bots. You look your part, a classic fat kid with wierd glasses that looks smart, this game does alot of that, using stereo types and issues in society like STD's. It uses all these things and makes jokes of them, which it manages to do with success. You have been captured by  the bots because you are too smart, you are put on a game show by bots for bots and your goal is to survive and escape the game show (as far as I could tell).  You are put through a bunch of challenges by the bots, you land on a planet you either defend from the bots or attack them, and there is always a timer to make sure some preasure is applied. By killing robots and their buildings you get money, in some levels you need a certain amount within the time limit and in some levels its just for the high score. However, you dont have any guns, or melee weapons, how do you kill bots? By fighting fire with fire, you use bots of your own to fight their bots, by spawning them from your mobile flying factory that is chained to you, you can accually defend yourself from the robots or attack their buildings.

Some robots fly, some walk, some drive, but they can all fight. For example some robots are used to blow up buildings on the fron lines and some are used to blow up buildings on the background. In some levels you get to place these buildings yourself. When you need to defend from the robots for example.

In many levels there is a difficulty slider where you can set how difficult you want the level to be. I have only played on 100% difficulty (probably the way the game is supposed to be played) but if a level is to hard you can half difficulty.

One thing i dont like about this game is that with the money you win you can buy extra bots to fight for you, special ones that are better but here is the deal, you get only one of them and one costs around 10 million I believe. In my oppinion this should be a matter of unlocking these bots and then you can spawn them in a challenge when you are able to spend your entire energy bar for example. Also with the money you win you can buy buildings, you can place one. I think it would be better if the amount you bought would be replenished at the start of every challenge.

The game lacks clarity of how to do things. A couple of times I ran into a situation where I finnaly realized after playing the level a couple of times what to do. The tutorial is a one time thing, meaning that once you click through it you cant get it back and you are on your own (as far as i know).

Graphics, sound and musicThe graphics of this game are cartoon-ish but with more detail which is nice. it fits the game well i think. After all the whole game is based around a future where the robots have taken over and are producing entertainment for dumb humans by putting smart humans through deadly challenges on TV. The sound is just as cartoony, same for the music, it fits this game well, it goes along with the art style which is think is one of the most important things for sound and music.

ConclusionIts a fun little game, with humor. I like the game because its goofy and you can quickly hop in and play the game for a few minutes. The gameplay itself is fun although it sometimes does not make it clear what, how, when or why. The single use bots and buildings are a minor downside since you could probably pass every level without them but i would like to see that change as i described before.

After taking all of this into consideration i give this game a 7/10. Its not a big game with tons of story to be had, the gameplay is simple yet fun. It could definatly improve on some pretty important aspects but i like it.

TL;DR7/10. Fun Gameplay, good Graphics, nice sound and music, but gameplay could be improved uppon in diffrent areas.

reviewText:
Death by Game Show:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Life in the 26th century is a bit strange to say the least! Take the example of U.H.Wutt who was tried in court for being too smart! Yes, you read it right. To make even worse, he was sentence to rehabilitation . . . In the 26th century, rehab means you are going to overcome serious challenges to stay alive, as you are being sent to this strange game show called. . .  Death by Game Show! Sounds like a walk in the park to me. Oh, I do not want to be rude but I think the game host is about to present our new contestant and I have the feeling it might be our dear U.H. Wutt!

Death by Game show is a strategy/action/tower defence game where you play the smart and groovy U.H.Wutt, who was sentenced to . . .  Death by Game Show! When the opening scene ends, you will be dropped by a rocket on a groovy stage show, where droids will take pictures of you (a bit like Japanese tourists, the flashlight never stops)! Here you will be able to see your next challenge, as well as the reward allocated for successfully completing the challenge. It might be reaching a specific number of points within a time frame to gain a structure or a new droid.

You will spawn on a field which will have an electronic fence on each end of the screen. These fences are not too far apart and all the action will take place within them. You will have to defend U.H.WUTT and his G.I.M.P.

The G.I.M.P is a giant floating locker strapped to you. It is also where your droids will spawn but it has a limited amount of energy. If the energy bar is at its lowest, you will still be able to order droids but they will be deployed rather slowly.  You will have up to 10 units to use, 6 special moves and 11 structures to choose from. You will be able to gain additional structures, units and special moves through the wheel of fortune (well, this is what I call it). To be able to spin the wheel you have to collect a specific number of coins. How do you get coins? It is rather simple; just destroy the enemy units and buildings, run over the coins or use your grapping tool to get them. As soon as you get the right number of coins, you will be able to use the wheel but it does not mean you‚Äòll get an extra unit, special move or structure - you could get nothing at all! Just the luck of the draw, I guess.  Just keep picking up coins! Plan and get the right gear to succeed in your next challenge.

This is a game that has a fair bit going on at once, and to be truly honest with you, could deter people. But I think it is a charm that makes this game stand out from the others! You will have plenty of failure, but as we say, a failure is one step closer to success.

I really like the artwork in this game, it just fits so well. Great humour too, I like really like the voice saying ‚ÄúGET TO THE CHOPPER!‚Äù The controls are fine but it will take you some time to get used to all the units, special moves and buildings.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Great artwork
-	Challenging and fun to play
-	Good humour
-	Plenty re-playability
-	Trading cards & Achievements

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Challenging levels can become frustrating at times

Death by Game Show is a challenging game with great artwork, humour and plenty of episodes/levels to play. Great fun!

9/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

A Tower-Defense game !Death by Game Show is designed for Tower-Defense game, but it's something so different.


This game is 2D strategy. Death by Game Show is a parody of reality shows, but just with robots and intelligent guy who is our main character/hero. Beggining is very easy, in level 1/2/3 you have some tutorials that help you a lot. Later, game becomes very hard. Graphic is very good for 2D game. I like the idea of our character/hero is way too smart, and is sentenced to rehabilitation. Main idea of the game is Avoiding dying. At begin, i thinked this is some boooring game, and i was not inderested in it. So i started playing. I was surprised. You should be interested in this game just by looking at the screenshots/pictures. Soundtrack is good, it have achievements and steam trading cards ! This game is fun, good and challenging.It's very unique. This is Lovely game, you can even try to improve a level for a hours and get the achievements. It was hard to find some Cons. back in the studio.

I - RECOMMEND THIS GAME TO EVERYONE !

reviewText:
I've followed this game since it was Greenlit, and it hasn't disappointed! Wonderful action strategy game with cartoon graphics and a Monty Python/Futurama sense of humour. The graphics in particular evoke memories as a kid of the Beano style comic annuals I used to read. Love the sound effects, especially ones that remind me of famous movie lines.

The gameplay is quick and action-packed, but still incorporates a degree of strategy and puzzle-solving so that you're rewarded for that  just one more go" way of approaching this. Tremendously satisfying!

I hope to see more games like this in the future: polished
hoursPlayed: but not sacrificing gameplay in any way.\n\nI just hope there's a sequel in the pipeline!!"

reviewText:
The basic information about this game:Name: Death by Game Show
Published by: Oointah
Released by: UltraShock Gaming
Date of release: 22 January 2016

Gameplay:The gameplay was at first not smooth, but if you go to settings and choose your own graphics and stuff, it's fixed and then it's very smooth! You play as a funny fat character with a hook that looks like the portal gun, and the physics gun. What does it do? I'm telling that later. But you are in a world that looks like another universe, and you are there the only human, you must do a bunch of funny mini-games, DON'T think that they are easy, they begin easy, but later they aren't that easy! If you gonna click on play, first there opens a red canvas, and then there is a kind of weird robot which is talking to you and is making jokes/puns, then you can start a mini-game. A rocket brings you to the place, and there are you: Such a random guy with a hook. NOW I gonna tell about that hook, it's for if you kill the evil bots that try to kill YOU. If they die, you get a coin or an item, and you can grab it with your hook, you need to do that, so you can fill a power-meter that gives you nice power-ups! Well, what to do in the game, it's a kind like a tower defence, so you must defend your place and spawn you OWN bots to fight with the evil ones. There are other missions too, you have uhm, defend your place, do the task you get, don't die, and a much more tasks. It was a really funny game, a little bit difficult to know what to do if you play it for the first time. I thought that you must do something with the hook, so I shoot the hook at the enemies, but nothing happened, because it's only for coins, power-ups, etc. I had to spawn my own bots, but I didn't knew that hahaha, so for me it was a little bit boring in the begin, but when I knew how to play it, I played it very long and enjoyed playing this game. I haven't encountered a fault or bug or glitch at all! So this game was for me a little bit special...

Conclusion:A very nice game, I think it's for the guys who really enjoy playing tower defence games quite much funnier! On the trade forum is not that much of activity now, but it‚Äôs coming! I'm also not that guy that plays tower defence games, but this one was fun, it was also a great experience to try a new game like this one, now I gonna give this game a rating, I'll give this game: 7,5 - 10. That's quite high, because I really liked it! Well, this was my review about this cool game! I hope you enjoyed reading this!
